page.title: 14FLORA IN THE HIGH WEALD
page.content: In spite of intensive grassland fields common meadow and woodland flowers abound in their season on uncultivated patches. In the spring hedgerows are often bottomed by{anemones, primroses and{bluebells,}woodland flowers which have remained after the land was cleared for farming. These are later replaced by{hedge parsley, foxgloves, {honeysuckle}and{wild roses. Moist acid soil and open glades in woodlands consisting of deep rooted trees like{oak,}are ideal sites for rhododendrons. The mauve or lilac {rhododendron ponticum}introduced into this country from Armenia and Asia has become well naturalised and is now considered a weed nuisance in forestry plantations. Other species and{azaleas have now been extensively planted for ornament in many of the gardens of the large houses.
